channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: [UN: Nov. 21] Ukraine’s Red Lines on US ‘Peace’ Plan, Mystery Planeload in South Africa & Lots More
item.description: This Week @UN: Can Gaza ever be stable?; Security Council OK’s Trump’s Gaza scheme; UN secretary-general race; restoring Africa’s famed Virunga forest; a woman UN Refugee boss? Plus: Mysterious planeload in South Africa; US-led Board of Peace; Syria’s sovereignty; Haiti’s endless gang rapes; Congolese massacres. Follow us on Blue Sky, Twitter (X), Facebook, Instagram and ... Read more

item.title: Global Fund raised $11.34 billion with a surprising US pledge
item.description: The U.S. showed unexpected levels of support, pledging $4.6 billion and maintaining its matching pledge ratio.

item.title: Sierra Leone challenges COP30 push for private sector to fund adaptation
item.description: Sierra Leone’s Minister for Environment and Climate Change Jiwoh Abdulai says that the private sector can’t meet adaptation needs.

item.title: COP30 reporters' notebook: Day 12
item.description: On the ground at the 30th United Nations Climate Change Conference, Devex reporters deliver the latest updates.

item.title: Soils hold 45% more carbon than thought, study finds
item.description: Soils hold far more carbon than once thought, making their protection central to climate action.

item.title: If COP30 Fails, It Won’t Be North vs. South, but Power vs People
item.description: Ginger Cassady is Executive Director, Rainforest Action Network

item.title: Devex Career Hub: How to new development consultants can break through
item.description: This week: how to get started as a global development consultant; who's hiring the most in India; featured new job leads; and more.

item.title: Is the Innovation Foundation a new model of corporate philanthropy?
item.description: The Innovation Foundation is using a social-lab model to scan public good-related challenges, build partnership ventures, and develop open-source tools and resources —deliberately shifting their model from transactional donor to catalyzing scalable community-led solutions.

item.title: Fighting filariasis: India's grassroots approach to eliminating elephantiasis
item.description: Despite carrying 40% of the global burden, India’s community-first approach, coupled with strong government coordination, is spurring progress toward a country free of lymphatic filariasis.

item.title: Rainwater Harvesting Mitigates Drought in Eastern Guatemala – VIDEO
item.description: Plagued by drought, farming families living within the boundaries of the Dry Corridor in eastern Guatemala have resorted to rainwater harvesting, an effective technique that has allowed them to cope. This enables them to obtain food from plots of land that would otherwise be difficult to farm. Funded by the Swedish government and implemented by […]

item.title: Devex Newswire: Civil society makes its case to G20 head honchos
item.description: Civil society sets its expectations for the Group of 20 largest economies. Plus, Sen. Chuck Grassley sets sights on U.S. foundations.

item.title: Gaza: Two children killed every day during fragile ceasefire, says UNICEF
item.description: Ongoing attacks and airstrikes attributed to Israeli forces in Gaza continue to kill and maim people of all ages in the shattered enclave despite an agreed ceasefire, UN agencies said on Friday.

item.title: Can industrial growth and climate action go hand in hand?
item.description: Do higher living standards in developing countries have to mean more polluting, fossil-fuel dependent industries? Or is a low-carbon alternative possible? As the world grapples with climate change, economic inequality, and rapid technological shifts, next week’s Global Industry Summit will tackle these questions, bringing together governments, business leaders, and innovators to shape solutions that balance prosperity with sustainability.

item.title: From waste pickers to courtrooms: Women demand a gender focus at COP30
item.description: On the scheduled final day of COP30 in Belém, tense negotiations are stretching into Friday afternoon as divisions persist. Amid the ongoing talks, one message is cutting through the noise: there is no climate justice without gender equality.

item.title: It’s time for leadership and vision, Guterres tells G20 in South Africa
item.description: A South African flag-coloured King Protea flower – symbolising hope and regeneration – is the chosen logo for this year’s G20 Leaders’ Summit, taking place on African soil for the first time.

item.title: UN presents UN80 Initiative Action Plan, setting coordinated path for system-wide reforms
item.description: The United Nations outlined how it intends to advance one of its most comprehensive system-wide reform efforts in decades, as Under-Secretary-General for Policy Guy Ryder presented the UN80 Initiative Action Plan. The plan brings the Secretary-General’s major UN80 reform proposals into a single, coherent structure to streamline efforts that will make the UN system deliver better.

item.title: UN decries ‘truly horrific’ massacres in DR Congo
item.description: Seventeen civilians, including women in labour and patients receiving care, were slaughtered inside a Catholic Church-run health centre in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) last week.

item.title: The top global development employers in India in 2025
item.description: In the past 12 months, India has seen sustained recruitment activity across the development sector. This article features the organizations that have posted the most opportunities in the country.

item.title: Trump’s approach to global health, and the latest from COP30
item.description: For the latest episode of our podcast series, Rumbi Chakamba sits down with Sara Jerving and Ayenat Mersie to discuss the top global development stories of the week.

item.title: Ex-top USAID official details wish list on health and funding fixes
item.description: Bill Steiger, former USAID chief of staff in the first Trump administration, warns Congress about biosecurity threats and backs push for greater global health self-reliance.

item.title: The Rising Threat of Digital Abuse: Women’s Vulnerability in the Age of AI and Online Harassment
item.description: As the digital landscape continues to expand and integrate into various aspects of daily life, humanitarian experts have raised concerns about the associated risks, particularly as artificial intelligence (AI), online anonymity, and the absence of effective monitoring frameworks heighten the potential for abuse and harassment. Women and girls are disproportionately affected by digital abuse, facing […]

item.title: The UN General Assembly, Over Burdened with Repetitive Resolutions, Aims at Revitalization
item.description: The 193-member General Assembly (GA), the UN’s highest policy-making body, has long been the repository for scores of long-winded outdated resolutions accumulated over several decades– and lying in cold storage. As part of the proposed restructuring of the United Nations, which is facing a severe liquidity crisis, there is now a move to streamline and […]

item.title: Evaluation Finds Food Systems Programs Deliver Results but Warns of Missed Transformation Chances
item.description: A new independent evaluation of the Global Environment Facility’s food systems programs says they are delivering strong environmental and livelihood gains in many countries but warns that a narrow focus on farm production, weak political analysis, and shrinking coordination budgets are holding back deeper transformation. The Evaluation of GEF Food Systems Programs, prepared by the GEF […]

item.title: School Days Lost, but Non-Economic Loss and Damage Not Part of Global Talks
item.description: Social impacts of climate change are already worsening, and long-term impacts can lead to stunted education. —Saqib Huq, Managing Director at the International Centre for Climate Change and Development
